title: China Eximbank provides RMB 210 million government concessional loan for the Lomé and 10 Interior Towns Electricity Distribution Network Project (Linked to Project ID#72803 and #72737)
description: On December 27, 2013, as part of a series of agreements signed (for these other agreements, see linked project ID#72803), Chinese Ambassador to Togo, Liu Yuxi, and Togolese Minister of Economy and Finance, Adji Othèth Ayassor, signed am RMB 210 million (or CFA 15 billion franc) preferential loan framework agreement for the Lomé and 10 Interior Towns Electricity Distribution Network Project. Then, on February 14, 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Economy and Finance of the Republic of Togo finalized the RMB 210 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the project. The loan (GCL) carried the following estimated borrowing terms: a 1.8728% interest rate, a 6.3639-year grace period, and a 20.2271-year maturity.  The proceeds of the loan were used to finance a commercial contract with TBEA that was signed on April 26, 2012.  China Eximbank disbursed $15,488,980 in support of the project in 2015.  The project involved the strengthening of an electricity distribution network in the capital city of Lomé and in 10 towns in the interior of Togo. TBEA Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation; its affiliate TBEA Nanjing Intelligent Electric Co., Ltd. was also involved in implementation. Togo's Ministry of Mines and Energy was the project's beneficiary ministry. The project has entered implementation because some of the loan proceeds have been disbursed, but its precise implementation start and end dates are unknown.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the second phase of the 161/66/20 kV Sokodé Substation and Transmission Line Construction Project. 2.  The first phase of the 161/66/20 kV Sokodé Substation and Transmission Line Construction Project was also financed by China Eximbank (as captured via Project ID#72737). 3. The French project title is Le renforcement et extension du réseau électrique de distribution de Lomé et des villes de l'intérieur or Le renforcement et l’extension du réseau de distribution de Lomé et de 10 villes de l’intérieur or Projet d'extension et de renforcement d'électricité. The Chinese project title is 多哥共和国各大城市及洛美周边地区配网巩固和扩建项目.4. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020. Nor is it included in the the Chinese Overseas Development Finance Dataset published by Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center in December 2020. 5. Some sources referred to the face value of the loan as CFA 15 billion francs. However, AidData has relied upon the RMB 210 million estimate since it is more likely that China Eximbank denominated this loan in RMB than in CFA.6.  The estimated borrowing terms (maturity, grace period, and interest rate) of the loan are drawn from the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS). See https://www.dropbox.com/s/2sw4f7gluxa52fk/DRS%20Official%20Commitments%20from%20China%20Through%202021.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/949n5rctiue6d7c/IDS_Average_grace_period_and_maturity_on_new_external_debt_commitments.xlsx?dl=0
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 210 million government concessional loan for the Lomé and 10 Interior Towns Electricity Distribution Network Project (Linked to Project ID#72803 and #72737)

# Description
On December 27, 2013, as part of a series of agreements signed (for these other agreements, see linked project ID#72803), Chinese Ambassador to Togo, Liu Yuxi, and Togolese Minister of Economy and Finance, Adji Othèth Ayassor, signed am RMB 210 million (or CFA 15 billion franc) preferential loan framework agreement for the Lomé and 10 Interior Towns Electricity Distribution Network Project. Then, on February 14, 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Economy and Finance of the Republic of Togo finalized the RMB 210 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the project. The loan (GCL) carried the following estimated borrowing terms: a 1.8728% interest rate, a 6.3639-year grace period, and a 20.2271-year maturity.  The proceeds of the loan were used to finance a commercial contract with TBEA that was signed on April 26, 2012.  China Eximbank disbursed $15,488,980 in support of the project in 2015.  The project involved the strengthening of an electricity distribution network in the capital city of Lomé and in 10 towns in the interior of Togo. TBEA Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation; its affiliate TBEA Nanjing Intelligent Electric Co., Ltd. was also involved in implementation. Togo's Ministry of Mines and Energy was the project's beneficiary ministry. The project has entered implementation because some of the loan proceeds have been disbursed, but its precise implementation start and end dates are unknown.
justification: Project focuses on strengthening electricity distribution networks, which is infrastructure supporting both renewable and non-renewable energy sources
evidence: Electricity distribution network in Lomé and 10 interior towns, grid infrastructure focus

title: Chinese Embassy and CRBC provide a CFA 18 million franc grant for the Sangbana Primary School Building Construction Project
description: In January 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Togo signed a framework agreement related to the Sangbana Primary School Building Construction Project. The Chinese Embassy and China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) — a Chinese state-owned enterprise — provided CFA 18 million francs for this project, which involved the construction of a school building at the Sangbana public primary school in the village of Kabou within the Bassar Prefecture. It was located near Togo’s northern border with Ghana.   The Sangbana primary school had aging facilities and few classrooms, forcing students of several grades to crowd together into a single classroom. The project sought to alleviate this issue by constructing a new building with three classrooms crowded into one classroom. The Chinese Embassy provided a batch of stationery and sporting goods for the school such as chairs, soccer balls, desks, workbooks, writing boards, sneakers, homework books, and desks.   The Togolese branch of CRBC — known locally as Société Nationale Chinoise des Ponts et des Chaussées (SNCPC-Togo)  — was the contractor responsible for implementation. The foundation stone laying ceremony for the school was held on January 14, 2014. It was attended by the Chinese Ambassador to Togo Liu Yuxi and former President of the Togolese National Assembly Bonfoh Abass.   At the ceremony, the Chinese Embassy presented donated stationary materials worth CFA 2 milllion francs to the students of the school. The donated items were worth CFA 2 million francs, as captured by linked project ID#73612. The completion and handover ceremony of the school was held on January 27, 2015, also attended by Liu and Bonfoh.
staff_comments: The French project title is Projet de construction d'un bâtiment scolaire à l'école primaire publique Sangbana. The 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that the framework agreement signed in January 2014 was a formal legal commitment.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy and CRBC provide a CFA 18 million franc grant for the Sangbana Primary School Building Construction Project

# Description
In January 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Togo signed a framework agreement related to the Sangbana Primary School Building Construction Project. The Chinese Embassy and China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) — a Chinese state-owned enterprise — provided CFA 18 million francs for this project, which involved the construction of a school building at the Sangbana public primary school in the village of Kabou within the Bassar Prefecture. It was located near Togo’s northern border with Ghana.   The Sangbana primary school had aging facilities and few classrooms, forcing students of several grades to crowd together into a single classroom. The project sought to alleviate this issue by constructing a new building with three classrooms crowded into one classroom. The Chinese Embassy provided a batch of stationery and sporting goods for the school such as chairs, soccer balls, desks, workbooks, writing boards, sneakers, homework books, and desks.   The Togolese branch of CRBC — known locally as Société Nationale Chinoise des Ponts et des Chaussées (SNCPC-Togo)  — was the contractor responsible for implementation. The foundation stone laying ceremony for the school was held on January 14, 2014. It was attended by the Chinese Ambassador to Togo Liu Yuxi and former President of the Togolese National Assembly Bonfoh Abass.   At the ceremony, the Chinese Embassy presented donated stationary materials worth CFA 2 milllion francs to the students of the school. The donated items were worth CFA 2 million francs, as captured by linked project ID#73612. The completion and handover ceremony of the school was held on January 27, 2015, also attended by Liu and Bonfoh.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of school building, provision of educational materials, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides $55 million loan for Phases 1 and 2 of Solar Street Light Installation Project
description: On November 23, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Togo signed a preferential loan framework agreement for Phases 1 and 2 of the Solar Street Light Installation Project. Then, near the end of 2014, China Eximbank and the Government of Togo signed a $55 million loan agreement for Phases 1 and 2 of the Solar Street Light Installation Project. This loan carried the following terms: a maturity of 25 years, a grace period of 5 years, and an estimated interest rate of 1.8728%.  The purpose of the project was to install 13,000 solar-powered streetlights across Togo. The installation of the solar-power streetlights was prioritized in dispensaries, schools, markets and other public places. The completed project was to provide lighting for 144 km of road, improving traffic safety at night.  Upon completion, the project was expected to facilitate a significant reduction in government spending on public street lighting (which totaled nearly $4 million in 2011‑2014) and bring Togo closer to its goal of using 10% renewable energy by 2020.  ZTE Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation; they also agreed to provide training on project maintenance to local personnel. The African Biofuel and Renewable Energy Company (SABER-ABREC) (also known as "Société africaine des biocarburants et des énergies renouvelables") collaborated with ZTE to implement the project. The project was placed under the supervision of Togo's Ministry of Energy and Mines.  In 2011, the Ministry of Mines and Energy conducted a feasibility study for the project. Phase 1 involved the installation of 7,042 solar street lights in more than 400 towns and villages in Togo. It began at the end of 2013 and was completed in August 2015. The second phase involved the construction of the remaining 5958 streetlights. Phase 2 began in mid-February 2016 and was originally expected to reach completion in June 2016. The project was ultimately completed sometime between March 2016 and August 2018 (likely around June 2016). A publication released in 2018 noted that the many of the solar-powered street lights were not lit up despite some being barely two years old.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Public Solar Street Light/Lamp Project. The Chinese project title is 太阳能照明系统项目 or 多哥太阳能路灯项目一期工程. The French project title is Projet de 13.000 lampadaires solaires or Le projet de développement de l’éclairage or Projet d’acquisition et d’installation de treize mille (13 000) lampadaires solaires au Togo.2.  The estimated interest rate of the loan is drawn from the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS). See https://www.dropbox.com/s/2sw4f7gluxa52fk/DRS%20Official%20Commitments%20from%20China%20Through%202021.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=0

# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $55 million loan for Phases 1 and 2 of Solar Street Light Installation Project

# Description
On November 23, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Togo signed a preferential loan framework agreement for Phases 1 and 2 of the Solar Street Light Installation Project. Then, near the end of 2014, China Eximbank and the Government of Togo signed a $55 million loan agreement for Phases 1 and 2 of the Solar Street Light Installation Project. This loan carried the following terms: a maturity of 25 years, a grace period of 5 years, and an estimated interest rate of 1.8728%.  The purpose of the project was to install 13,000 solar-powered streetlights across Togo. The installation of the solar-power streetlights was prioritized in dispensaries, schools, markets and other public places. The completed project was to provide lighting for 144 km of road, improving traffic safety at night.  Upon completion, the project was expected to facilitate a significant reduction in government spending on public street lighting (which totaled nearly $4 million in 2011‑2014) and bring Togo closer to its goal of using 10% renewable energy by 2020.  ZTE Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation; they also agreed to provide training on project maintenance to local personnel. The African Biofuel and Renewable Energy Company (SABER-ABREC) (also known as "Société africaine des biocarburants et des énergies renouvelables") collaborated with ZTE to implement the project. The project was placed under the supervision of Togo's Ministry of Energy and Mines.  In 2011, the Ministry of Mines and Energy conducted a feasibility study for the project. Phase 1 involved the installation of 7,042 solar street lights in more than 400 towns and villages in Togo. It began at the end of 2013 and was completed in August 2015. The second phase involved the construction of the remaining 5958 streetlights. Phase 2 began in mid-February 2016 and was originally expected to reach completion in June 2016. The project was ultimately completed sometime between March 2016 and August 2018 (likely around June 2016). A publication released in 2018 noted that the many of the solar-powered street lights were not lit up despite some being barely two years old.
justification: Primary purpose is installation of solar-powered streetlights, directly supporting renewable energy adoption
evidence: 13,000 solar-powered streetlights, reduction in government spending on public lighting, contribution to Togo's renewable energy goals

title: China donates 296 million FCFA in equipment to Kara Regional Hospital
description: In January 2014, the new Chinese Ambassador to Togo, Liu Yuxi, visited the Kara Regional Hospital Center, commonly known as the Chinese hospital of Tomde. During his visit, the Ambassador announced the renewal of a donation of medical equipment worth 296,000,000 FCFA to the hospital.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates 296 million FCFA in equipment to Kara Regional Hospital

# Description
In January 2014, the new Chinese Ambassador to Togo, Liu Yuxi, visited the Kara Regional Hospital Center, commonly known as the Chinese hospital of Tomde. During his visit, the Ambassador announced the renewal of a donation of medical equipment worth 296,000,000 FCFA to the hospital.
justification: Project involves donation of medical equipment to a hospital, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical equipment donation to Kara Regional Hospital, healthcare sector focus

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 628 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of Lomé Bypass Road Development and Asphalting Project (Linked to Project ID#68450 and #72803)
description: On December 27, 2013, the Chinese Government and the Government of Togo signed an RMB 628 million (CFA 49.282 billion franc) preferential loan framework agreement for the Phase 2 of Lomé Bypass Road Development and Asphalting Project (as captured via Project ID#72803). Then, on February 14, 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Economy and Finance of the Republic of Togo signed a government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 2 of the Lomé Bypass Road Development and Asphalting Project). The loan (GCL) carried the following estimated borrowing terms: a 1.8728% interest rate, a 6.3639-year grace period, and a 20.2271-year maturity.  The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance a commercial contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC). When the commercial contract [Marché N° 010/2008/MTPT/SG/DGTP] was initially issued on November 6, 2008, its value was $70,278,490,37. However, it was modified on June 2, 2014 and its value was increased to $98,831,214.  According to 2014, 2015, and 2016 reports published by the Bilateral Cooperation Department of Togo’s Ministry of Planning and Development, the GCL disbursed $49,090,342 in 2014, $11,108,065 in 2015, and $526,981 in 2016.  Phase 2 involved the development and asphalting of a 20.54 km road segment between the Golf Club de Lomé (along National Route 1 or RN1) and the town of Noépé, on Togo’s border with Ghana. The entire ring road was a four lane, 34.8 kilometers long road in the eastern and northern parts of Lomé. The second phase specifically focused on creating roads to allow trucks to travel to Ghana, Côte d'Ivoire or Burkina Faso, without being forced to use the congested arteries of downtown Lomé; it also included the renovation of secondary roads.   CRBC was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project commenced on September 10, 2015 and was originally scheduled for completion in May 2019. However, the project faced a number of delays related to the freeing of the right-of-way by locals. As of August 2017, the project had achieved a 31% completion rate. As of November 2018, it had achieved a 67.2% completion rate. By September 2019, the project was nearing completion. The project was completed by August 2020, but its precise completion date is unknown.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 的多哥洛美绕城二期 or 洛美绕城公路项目（第二阶段) or 绕城公路二期. The French project title is La Seconde phase du contournement de Lomé or Le second contournement de Lomé or la 2è phase du projet du grand contournement de Lomé. 2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020.3.  The estimated borrowing terms (maturity, grace period, and interest rate) of the loan are drawn from the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS). See https://www.dropbox.com/s/2sw4f7gluxa52fk/DRS%20Official%20Commitments%20from%20China%20Through%202021.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/949n5rctiue6d7c/IDS_Average_grace_period_and_maturity_on_new_external_debt_commitments.xlsx?dl=0

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 628 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of Lomé Bypass Road Development and Asphalting Project (Linked to Project ID#68450 and #72803)

# Description
On December 27, 2013, the Chinese Government and the Government of Togo signed an RMB 628 million (CFA 49.282 billion franc) preferential loan framework agreement for the Phase 2 of Lomé Bypass Road Development and Asphalting Project (as captured via Project ID#72803). Then, on February 14, 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Economy and Finance of the Republic of Togo signed a government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 2 of the Lomé Bypass Road Development and Asphalting Project). The loan (GCL) carried the following estimated borrowing terms: a 1.8728% interest rate, a 6.3639-year grace period, and a 20.2271-year maturity.  The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance a commercial contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC). When the commercial contract [Marché N° 010/2008/MTPT/SG/DGTP] was initially issued on November 6, 2008, its value was $70,278,490,37. However, it was modified on June 2, 2014 and its value was increased to $98,831,214.  According to 2014, 2015, and 2016 reports published by the Bilateral Cooperation Department of Togo’s Ministry of Planning and Development, the GCL disbursed $49,090,342 in 2014, $11,108,065 in 2015, and $526,981 in 2016.  Phase 2 involved the development and asphalting of a 20.54 km road segment between the Golf Club de Lomé (along National Route 1 or RN1) and the town of Noépé, on Togo’s border with Ghana. The entire ring road was a four lane, 34.8 kilometers long road in the eastern and northern parts of Lomé. The second phase specifically focused on creating roads to allow trucks to travel to Ghana, Côte d'Ivoire or Burkina Faso, without being forced to use the congested arteries of downtown Lomé; it also included the renovation of secondary roads.   CRBC was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project commenced on September 10, 2015 and was originally scheduled for completion in May 2019. However, the project faced a number of delays related to the freeing of the right-of-way by locals. As of August 2017, the project had achieved a 31% completion rate. As of November 2018, it had achieved a 67.2% completion rate. By September 2019, the project was nearing completion. The project was completed by August 2020, but its precise completion date is unknown.
justification: Road development project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts

title: China finances martial arts school in Togo
description: On November 27, 2014, the Chinese Martial Arts School (多哥洛美中华武术学校 or Chinese Martial Arts Center or CMACT) in Lomé was officially inaugurated. The value of this project is unknown, but it was most likely financed by a grant from the Chinese government.   Four graduates from the Shaolin Temple school of kung fu manage CMACT as well as offer Chinese-language classes for 15,000 FCFA/month.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China finances martial arts school in Togo

# Description
On November 27, 2014, the Chinese Martial Arts School (多哥洛美中华武术学校 or Chinese Martial Arts Center or CMACT) in Lomé was officially inaugurated. The value of this project is unknown, but it was most likely financed by a grant from the Chinese government.   Four graduates from the Shaolin Temple school of kung fu manage CMACT as well as offer Chinese-language classes for 15,000 FCFA/month.
justification: Project is focused on cultural and educational activities without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Martial arts school with Chinese language classes, social infrastructure focus

title: Chinese Embassy donates CFA 2 million worth of stationary materials and sporting goods to the students of the Sangbana Primary School (Linked to Project ID#53494)
description: On January 14, 2014, during the foundation laying ceremony of the Sangbana Primary School Building Construction Project (see linked project ID#53494), the Chinese Embassy donated stationary materials such as soccer balls, school bags, notebooks, and sneakers to the students of the school. The donated items were worth CFA 2 million francs (see "S.E.M LIU Yuxi Ambassadeur de Chine a présidé la cérémonie de pose de la première pierre du projet de construction d'un bâtiment scolaire à l'école primaire publique Sangbana").

title: China signs a grant for CFA 47 million for the construction of the Center for Documentation and Information at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation of Togo
description: During the June 20-22, 2014 of the Chinese Vice Foreign Minister in charge of African Affairs, Zhang Ming, a grant agreement of 47 million CFA was signed to support the Center for Documentation and Information at the Togolese Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation.

GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

China signs a grant for CFA 47 million for the construction of the Center for Documentation and Information at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation of Togo

During the June 20-22, 2014 of the Chinese Vice Foreign Minister in charge of African Affairs, Zhang Ming, a grant agreement of 47 million CFA was signed to support the Center for Documentation and Information at the Togolese Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation.

title: China grants $27,000 USD in food aid for cyclone victims (linked to projects #39198, #73440, #65923)
description: On January 15, 2014, China donated food aid worth $27,000 USD to Tonga for victims of Cyclone Ian. These were handed over to Tonga's Prime Minister by China's Ambassador to Tonga. This project is linked to #39198, which records a cash and aid supplies grant from China to Tonga, #73440, which records a construction materials grant from the Yanjian group, and #65923, which records an additional Chinese cash grant. All of these are for relief and rehabilitation following Cyclone Ian.
combined_text:

EMERGENCY RESPONSE

This project is linked to #39198, which records a cash and aid supplies grant from China to Tonga, #73440, which records a construction materials grant from the Yanjian group, and #65923, which records an additional Chinese cash grant. All of these are for relief and rehabilitation following Cyclone Ian.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and disaster relief without direct environmental or energy transition impacts

title: Chinese Government donates Y-12 aircraft worth $7.4 million (Linked to Project ID#37733)
description: On October 10, 2014, the Chinese Ambassador to Tonga, Huang Huaguang, and the Prime Minister of Tonga, Vajru, signed a handover certificate of the donation of Y-12 aircraft. The handover ceremony took place in the presence of it over to King Tupou VI at Lupepau'u Airport in Vava'u. The 17-seat aircraft was manufactured in China by the Aviation Industry Corporation of China at a cost of approximately $7.4 million.   This was the second aircraft donated to the Government of Tonga by the Chinese Government, the first being an MA60 donated in 2013 (as recorded in Project ID#37733). The total cost of construction for these two planes was $20 million USD. In 2015, it was reported that this plane experienced mechanical issues with the brakes. This plane was at the time operated by Real Tonga Airlines
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government donates Y-12 aircraft worth $7.4 million (Linked to Project ID#37733)

# Description
On October 10, 2014, the Chinese Ambassador to Tonga, Huang Huaguang, and the Prime Minister of Tonga, Vajru, signed a handover certificate of the donation of Y-12 aircraft. The handover ceremony took place in the presence of it over to King Tupou VI at Lupepau'u Airport in Vava'u. The 17-seat aircraft was manufactured in China by the Aviation Industry Corporation of China at a cost of approximately $7.4 million.   This was the second aircraft donated to the Government of Tonga by the Chinese Government, the first being an MA60 donated in 2013 (as recorded in Project ID#37733). The total cost of construction for these two planes was $20 million USD. In 2015, it was reported that this plane experienced mechanical issues with the brakes. This plane was at the time operated by Real Tonga Airlines
justification: Aircraft donation is a general infrastructure project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of Y-12 aircraft for transportation purposes, no mention of environmental or energy-related aspects
